title: AB 1847
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature amended Section 19851 of the Revenue and Taxation Code to address the low participation rate in the federal Earned Income Tax Credit program. In 2015, California authorized a state EITC to help the poorest working Californians. In 2015, California authorized a state EITC to amplify the poverty-reducing effects of the federal EITC for the poorest working Californians. The state aims to alleviate the tax burden on working poor individuals and families, enhance their wages and income, ensure access to both federal and state EITC, and inject additional federal money into the California economy through information dissemination. California authorized a state EITC in 2015 to complement the federal EITC for the poorest working Californians. Employers and state departments provide notices to ensure eligible individuals claim both credits. The Revenue and Taxation Code is amended to define terms related to the EITC. The Revenue and Taxation Code is amended to require employers to notify employees about eligibility for federal and California EITC. State departments and agencies serving potential EITC qualifiers are specified. State departments and agencies must inform program recipients annually about potential eligibility for federal and California EITC, either in January through April or during regular contact. Indirect communication through other entities serving eligible individuals is allowed. Effective notification methods are encouraged as long as the message aligns with specified language requirements. The employer must provide notification to employees about the availability of federal and California EITC either in person or by mail. Posting notices on bulletin boards or sending through office mail is not sufficient. The notice must contain specific language requirements and amendments to the section apply to notices given after the effective date of the act. Based on your annual earnings, you may be eligible for the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) from the federal government. The EITC is a refundable federal income tax credit for low-income working individuals and families. It does not affect certain welfare benefits. You must file a federal tax return to receive the EITC, even if you do not owe federal taxes. Contact the Internal Revenue Service for more information on eligibility and how to obtain necessary forms. The California Earned Income Tax Credit (California EITC) is available starting from the 2015 tax year for low-income working individuals and families. To claim the California EITC, file a California income tax return and attach form FTB 3514. Contact the Franchise Tax Board for more information on eligibility and assistance with filing. Amendments to this section apply to notices provided after the effective date of the act.
